A summary of all the micro-posts that I might have syndicated elsewhere. Quite a bit of the functionality on this page might be broken.

03 Aug 2025:

    Tweaked the maps page to reflect posts that have a set location. Currently this is a super vanilla layout and I think I should cluster these by region. I do like how it’s turned out though!

    While at it, I realised I missed downloading pictures from my old Flickr account to Nextcloud. Brought those in and nuked the Flickr account. 🔗

      Dinner at Vietnamese restaurant Thaonhi was great! Bangui does seem to have a decent restaurant scene!

      29 Jul 2025:

        Regular day at work.

        Gunny takes us to 5 Fourchettes for dinner. Some pretty good food with terrific company.

        28 Jul 2025:

          Took us about 5 hours to get to Douala from Yaounde. The A1 route doesn’t show up on Google maps but does on OSMAnd.

          Decided to grab a bite at Hotel H. Food was good!

          Head straight to the airport from there. Pretty uneventful flight but for the ‘hot’ landing in Bangui. Expediter got us out fast! WPS folks got us to the lodge. Pretty minimal but just sufficient housing. The Orange internet box does’t work. Thankfully Airtel roaming does!

          26 Jul 2025:

          Setup these three meshtastic T1000-E radio’s today. Amazed at how tiny yet powerful these are. They seem to last for about three days with GPS and telemetry on. Until Meshtastic enables all the sensors I might probably box these up. In a pinch these can always be used for mesh’d comms if needed. 🔗

          19 Jul 2025:

            We’d initially planned on visiting HongKong to celebrate Patti’s 80th and then head to India for a short trip for our R&R. Mummyjaan’s heart decided nah-ah and we ended up in Dubai. Once I knew she was stable and was receiving the care she needed, I decided to head to India. In a week, I covered 6 cities spending barely a night in each place. Visiting Pune was most fulfilling. Didn’t quite get to meet friends that I planned to meet in Hyderabad but got some local sightseeing checked off the list for family. Was great meeting family in Ahmedabad but I am NOT going back there in summer. So glad I made it to Trivandrum to meet Raju Mama. Drive to Ernakulam wasn’t quite planned but I guess that happened. Always fun visiting Ron in Bangalore but the flying Madras trip was one last minute surprise.

            While I got to meet some friends and family, In hindsight, this trip was nuts. Way too much travel and strain. I think henceforth, I’m just going to stay a bit longer in one city and have whoever wants to meet come over. We’d initially cost-constructed this trip. Turned out to be one hell of a cost-construct! Just so happy to be back home! 🔗

            19 Jul 2025:

              It’s a weird feeling. To not be presence-aware of someone 24x7.

              Until now, S had either been with both M and I or just M when I travel for work. I haven’t had the chance to be with just S alone for a long stretch. Until last week. M&I thought it might be a good idea for her to travel with me from Dubai. It felt like she matured all of a sudden during Mummyjaan’s hospitalization. Maybe she sensed the stress all around her and adapted?

              As S traveled with me, zipping across 6 cities, I felt I was constantly on the hook. How much buffer time do I need to get her ready? Did she use the bathroom before we head out? Did I keep a spare set of clothes with me? Will I find the food that she might like in the new place? If not, did I have enough snack options for her? Do I need to get her clothes washed in this city or the next? Which PJ set would she like tonight? How do I coax her to sleep despite all the flux around her? What am I forgetting?…

              And to not do that, now that she isn’t with me, It feels odd. And then, when it actually dawns that M’s doing this more or less 24x7x365 - besides the gazillion other things she does; I think the least I can do is get involved a lot more. 🔗

              18 Jul 2025:

                M called in sick around 0630. Decided to head to Chennai to drop S and get back to B’lore for my flight to YND. This trip has been meh over meh…So many last minute changes. Hopefully things settle down a bit over the next few days.

                Overheard someone talking about actuarial modeling in the airport. Some good conversation and we left for our gates. Can’t believe it’s been 10 years since I went on that career path!

                17 Jul 2025:

                  Decide to wake S up around 1000. She’s definitely got some good sleep in. Ron picks us from the hotel and we head to a few breakfast joints for some more dosas and coffee.

                  A quick stop at his place and we then head to their office. Super glad to see them doing really well. Pretty sure none of this was easy. Both of them are constantly on calls keeping tabs on multiple things.

                  Met Tanishq, one of Ron’s kids from TFI. She’s now working in Frontlyne and soon to be the lead. So proud!

                  Head to Parsa’s for some delicious Kashmiri lunch. Gulped multiple cups of the kawa. Beautiful seating and super laid back. A good long visit to the Himalayas is long overdue.

                  We head to the aquarium from here. S loved it! Was super small but really well maintained.

                  Called it a night after some great pav bhaji at Ron’s place.

                  M seems to be coming down with something. Hopefully this is just a minor thing…

                  16 Jul 2025:

                    I snooze the alarm at 0600 and end up sleeping in till 0730. Mumma calls to check if she should get S ready. Plan was to leave ERN by 0800 so we could make it in time for our 1735 flight from TVM.

                    Quick breakfast at the Travancore Court and we leave ERN around 0900. S slept through most of the ride and making barely a couple stops enroute we reached TVM by around 1515. Super smooth drive. Amazed at how well maintained and clean these roads are.

                    S enjoyed a decent meal at the lounge in the airport. In B’lore, we have a super quick transition to the baggage claim and hop on a BMTC heading to Jayanagar 4th. But for a few waterlogged stops, we get to Jayanagar 4th in about 2 hours. A LOT of traffic but smooth flowing. Ron mentions later this is likely due to the automated traffic control system across the city. We head to Cafe Amudham for dinner followed by Baskin’Robins for icecream. Some of the best dosas I’ve had in a while. Also black currant ice cream!!

                    Get to the hotel around 2300 and get some much deserved sleep. Last few days have been beyond hectic and exactly what I would like to avoid in trips henceforth.

                    15 Jul 2025:

                      Plan’s to head to ERN to see Padmagireesan mama. His health’s been on a downward spiral for a few months now.

                      Mumma drops S at 0800 and Daphne folks head to Padmanabhaswamy temple for an early morning darshan. I sleep in. We leave TVM around 1200. As I sit in the car, it looms on me what I’ve committed to. 7 hrs today and 7 hours back tomorrow in the car is going to be rough on S. Heck, I’m not psyched about this too. But Mama was really excited about the trip and I didnt want to be the one saying no…

                      Around 1500 we hear mama has passed away. In my mind I’m actually glad he did. He’s been going through this for a while now and it was only a question of time…

                      We make it to ERN by around 2000. Not a bad drive. Just tiring. Kids love the hotel. Mamaji enjoys the Jeera rice and dal Fry. We head to Panampilly nagar after this. A bit surprised the close family was shocked..but I guess I’m the last person to understand emotions…Also maybe loosing Amma pretty young has made me numb to death? It consumes you slowly memory by memory at moments you’d least expect.RIP mammaji.

                      Back to the hotel around 2300 and try and get some sleep. Tomorrow is going to be a long day…

                      14 Jul 2025:

                        It’s been a super rough night. S has been stirring all night sweating loads. I’ve barely caught any sleep. Maybe the poor ventilation in the room upstairs or just the hot humid A’bad heat..We wake up around 0400 and get ready to leave for the 0755 flight to TVM. Suresh Anna drops us in the airport giving us a quick morning tour of A’bad. Next time around I’m only coming here during winter.

                        On arrival in TVM, we head straight to Lalit Mahal, right by the Padmanabhaswamy temple. Daphne folks checkin there and we head to Vijayam Periammai’s house for some epic lunch. Felt like a sadya! Raju Mama had come there. Boy, has he aged? So freaking disturbing to see him grow old all by himself. Not being there to take care of him will be one of my top regrets for a long time to come. Probably one of the biggest downsides of this career…

                        Mama and I take S to Shangumugam beach and then head home to Thanu Nagar. S wants to sleep with the kids in the hotel. We grab a quick dinner in Annapoorani and head back home. Doesn’t take me long to get knocked out.

                          12 Jul 2025:

                            Covered Golconda fort, Qutub Shahi tombs and Charminar before we head to AJ. Hot day out but most of them had a great time.

                            Golconda fort and Charminar were probably the highlight. Spent more than a couple hours in Golconda meandering through the various fort ruins. Six of us piled into one auto and made it to Qutib Shahi tombs. All of us had a good chuckle as Pattar held on to the rickshaw drivers hand instead of the support when he sat in front with the driver. “Arre, inno haath kaiko pakkadra miyan”.

                            Took two separate rickshaws from Qutub Shaving tombs to Charminar. Kids and daddy were definitely offput by the pollution and congested traffic as we neared Charminar. Daddy didn’t want to come at first but some enticement with Irani chai did the trick. Took me a minute to figure out where Nimrah cafe was. With all the street side vendors you could barely spot it. This used to be one of my goto rides early in the morning!

                            Got two rickshaws to get out of the congestion and head to MGBS and took the metro from MGBS to habsiguda.Autorickshaw rides, streetside haggling, Metro rides, they got it all.

                            AJ looks great thanks to the mega cleaning they got done yesterday. Barely spent a couple hours here and head out for dinner.

                            Dinner was a disappointment. Basera no longer has Mehfil and the Uppu restaurant that’s currently open there was a non-pleaser.

                                  19 Jun 2025:

                                    To the recent air-crash. To the Iran-Israel escalation. To the Israel-Palestine conflict. To the massive layoffs happening all over the federal space. To the incessant pollution on the roads. To the mindless spending all over. To the massive disparity across realms.

                                    Walking over to Masks for a couple drinks and that falafel burger. Playing Breath of the WIld like nobody’s business. Debating pros and cons of a neuro program in UCL. Ordering multiple T1000Es to tinker with. Planning future travel across waters. Living in this messed up world, raising a kid just like those gazillion out there who’re going to wonder what the heck their parents and ancestors did and did’nt do.

                                    All of this does not compute. Numb at so many levels… 🔗

                                    15 Jun 2025:

                                    The short rainy season is almost about to end here. There’s still no dearth of monsoon drama though. A warm and humid afternoon leads in to a breezy evening. In just a few moments, it feels like you’ve been transported to a coastal town. The surrounding hills lock in the clouds and the barometric pressure drops. Denser dark clouds churn their way up and magnificently roll up the hills only to be forced down. Small static crackles lead in to thunderous lightnings, all in a matter of few minutes.

                                    Cocooned in a hammock, music by the side with this little one observing all the moves and doling out a cascade of chuckles from things related and not. Little joys.

                                        06 Jun 2025:

                                          Bailing out to the new media - Will we though? In some form or fashion those that are leaving are probably just finding a different medium where they’re able to connect better? I actually think there are more people blogging now than before. Just in different dispersed mediums.

                                          And actually if we do, wouldn’t that be just the ebbs and flows of a social framework? People come in, people leave. You make a connection here and a connection there and hope to linger in that ether of those network connections that’s always in a flux. Also isn’t blogging a sort of ’new media’ when compared to postcards or aerogram? When was the last time you sent or received one?🔗

                                              25 May 2025:

                                                I used WithKnown for about a minute several years ago. Loved the interface and software but it never really stood the test of time. Yesterday, while searching for older posts related to Uganda, I realized, I never quite moved those posts over. Spent about an hour yesterday and migrated those over to this portal. While at it, I also migrated my old twitter posts over. And with that I think all content is now present on this portal. Since the feed settings are limited to 10 most recent posts, I’m pretty sure this shouldn’t spam the RSS feeds. 🔗

                                                  19 May 2025:

                                                    19 May 2025:

                                                      Today was supposed to be a ‘Bridged’ holiday. In this part of the world, the president apparently declares certain days to be holidays if they happen to fall adjacent to a previously declared public holiday and the weekend.

                                                      With tomorrow being Cameroon day, rumor was that today would be one of those bridged holidays. Sadly it wasn’t. Locally employed staff were definitely not happy. The Ambo did declare a 59 minute early release. Got the message while we were amidst a small project and not quite at a good stopping point. So we chugged along and head home when we were done. Will take it in spirit though. Merci Beaucoup! 🔗

                                                      18 May 2025:

                                                        Switched over to an unlimited connection with Orange. For some weird reason, it costs half the price of a limited 60GB connection. Speeds seem to be all the same..for now.

                                                        Swam 10 laps this afternoon. Need to get that froggy out and freestyle in.

                                                        15 May 2025:

                                                          Back from a work trip in Malabo. Got there last Thursday and worked through the weekend. We completed a minor site upgrade and completed almost all of the planned work.

                                                          Didn’t quite get to explore any of the island since we were mostly shuttling back and forth from work. From what little I did get to see though, this place is beautiful. Between China’s belt and road initiative and the island’s oil money from the 90s, Infrastructure looked to be quite top notch. The airport terminal is quite spiffy.

                                                          Food was mediocre at best. The Magno hotel has a decent restaurant. Next time I’m here I should probably come over the weekend to explore the cafe’s and the boardwalk a bit.

                                                          The ~230 Ft towering Ceiba tree in the embassy compound is a terrific sight. Apparently this tree is quite prevalent all across Africa.

                                                          Internet in the hotel was barely functional - for call’s atleast. Looks like some port-blocking was definitely at play. Not having those daily calls back home maybe also made the trip feel a bit longer that it actually was? Need to go better prepared next time! 🔗

                                                                                        26 Mar 2025:

                                                                                        Photos from our recent trip the Glen Canyon National Recreation area from 24th March, 25th March and 26th March.

                                                                                        27 Mar 2025:

                                                                                          Left home for the airport around 0500 to depart Vegas and head to Seattle.

                                                                                          Got the Seattle rental on M’s name so I didn’t have to do all the driving. Drive to Kirkland took barely about 30 minutes! Feels so good to be back to colder climes!

                                                                                          26 Mar 2025:

                                                                                            We decide against doing Zion National park in this trip. Wouldn’t be able to do justice with the short time we had and more importantly, I didn’t quite have any gear with me.

                                                                                            Checkout from the hotel in Hurricane and decide to stop at the Valley of fire state park and Hoover dam on our way back to LV. The 50 mile scenic drive in the Lake Mead NRA was pretty cool.

                                                                                            Join the Subnavis’ for dinner at Thailicious and help them move their TV to their new home.

                                                                                            25 Mar 2025:

                                                                                              We head to the Lake Powell Marina for our boat tour first thing this morning. Just us and an old Chinese couple. The captain apparently does charter tours mostly and was filling in for somebody else. Over the couple hours he gives us a pretty good overview of Lake Powell and the Glen Canyon Dam. Amazed at the scale of the Colorado river - with a depth of around 400ft and about 250 miles long between the the Glen Canyon dam and the Hoover Dam. Note to self to watch DamNation.

                                                                                              Grab a quick bite at Dari Thai and head to Canyon X for a slot canyon tour. The guide does a great job showing how these slot canyons are formed. S enjoys this way better than the boat tour.

                                                                                              From there we head back towards Hurricane stopping at Toadstool hoodoos for a short hike. Grab a quick bite at a small cafe and check-in to a hotel for the night.

                                                                                              24 Mar 2025:

                                                                                                Slightly side tracked by the Black rifle coffee, we leave around 0900 for the Glen Canyon National Recreational Area. In about four hours we get to the Glen canyon dam. M helps S with her junior ranger book while I stroll around the visitor center soaking in this majestic beauty.

                                                                                                We head straight to Horseshoe bend. About a 1.6 mile roudtrip hike from the parking lot. Both S & I feel the heat and the super crowded trail doesn’t help either. We grab a few photos and make our way back to the parking.

                                                                                                                                05 Feb 2025:

                                                                                                                                I bit the bullet and setup a rudimentary comment system for this site. For the last few months, I relied on ISSO, but it kinda felt a bit too heavy. Finally scratched the itch and switched over to a basic form and some javascript to push comments over to my self-hosted ntfy server. For now, I’ve left the moderation to manual mode - I have to copy over the comments manually from NTFY to a comments.json file. A GO script that usually publishes this site also builds the comments for each of the posts as needed based on the posts’ permalink. Pretty friction-less and nifty! 🔗

                                                                                                                                  10 Jan 2025:

                                                                                                                                    /s This turned out to be simpler than I thought.                                                                                                                                       24 Dec 2024:

                                                                                                                                      Downhill and no brakes, what fun! Definitely not at that moment though. Somewhere near Cuernavaca, The Grand Vitara had a brake fade 1 this morning on our way to Las Estacas. The brakes would just not work and it felt like I had to pump it to get even a bit of traction. Got super close to hitting the car in front of us but thankfully, I found a small lane (ditch?) to veer off from the traffic and engine braked it to a stop. Super lucky none of us were hurt and we were able to veer away from traffic just in time. Also lucky that this happened just about 100m from a mechanic shop! What are the odds? Took them about three hours to do a thorough check on all four wheels and fix the oil reservoir tray - which they broke while jacking the car up. Oh boy, what a start to this years’ Christmas!

                                                                                                                                      Immediately after we were able to get the vehicle to a stop, M asked if it was the floor mat that was the culprit. Nope - I’d removed them a few days after we bought this car. All thanks to another dreadful experience several years ago in the Grand Cherokee.

                                                                                                                                      Ignorance and oversight only make sense in hindsight. About fifteen minutes before this incident, I did notice the brakes feeling soft and remember thinking - that’s odd the brakes worked just fine so far. Also maybe I didn’t notice the smoke from the tires because we were driving through quasi dirt roads? All signs of the brakes giving in - had I known about brake fade then. Wee bit wiser now I guess? 🔗

                                                                                                                                      1. Apparently that is the technical term for a failed brake. ↩︎

                                                                                                                                                    01 Dec 2024:

                                                                                                                                                      Moved over the syndication links in my posts to post-meta. The syndication icon only shows up if a valid link is present in the FrontMatter of a post. Once micro.blog picks up the feed, it’s currently set to auto publish to the fediverse on my GoToSocial (GTS) instance. On the backend, a GO script fetches the RSS feed from my GTS instance and saves the RSS feed item link and the corresponding link to my post in a JSON file. Another script quickly looks up which post’s FrontMatter needs to be updated for the syndication links in each post and updates the files as needed. A bit windy but seems to do the job for now. I might end up consolidating these into just one script later and/or directly use the masto API to publish to the fediverse and grab the syndication link from there. For now, I’m pretty psyched this is all working.

                                                                                                                                                              13 Jul 2024:

                                                                                                                                                                The pains and joys of self-hosting and tinkering.                                                                                                                                                                 21 Jun 2024:

                                                                                                                                                                  M and I tend to share photos with family and friends on various chat groups. While straightforward, It felt redundant to share copies of the same pictures in multiple places. I’ve been looking for options to share album links instead that would give us a bit more control. All our photos are primarily saved in a Nextcloud self-hosted instance. I explored a few options of album shares there but wasn’t quite happy. Pixelfed was another option I explored. It did check most of the requirements but I wasn’t quite comfortable relying on a software that’s mostly dependent on just one developer. Also the unlisted feature on their albums seemed half-baked and not yet ready for prime-time. Finally played a bit with PhotoPrism and so far it seems to be something that checks all the boxes. With private links, a PWA app and great thumbnails this might be the closest solution for my photo needs.

                                                                                                                                                                          17 May 2024:

                                                                                                                                                                            14 Apr 2024:

                                                                                                                                                                            S was having a rough day on Saturday and was scrunched up against me all day. Around 1900 I checked my work phone and saw that Mo had texted earlier that morning asking if I would be interested in hiking Pico de Aguilar the next day. Thankfully, on Sunday morning, S seemed to have almost recovered and I decide to head out to meet Mo at his place. With some starting troubles (literally!) we finally leave for Ajusco around 0830.

                                                                                                                                                                            The drive up is super straightforward and we park at the trailhead around 1000. We decide to take on the steeper parts of the climb first going clockwise. Around 1200 we reach Pico de Águila (12596’) and in another 30 minutes we summit Cerro La Cruz del Marquez (12871’). The way down from the Cerro was super steep at an 82° gradient. So glad we decided not to climb up from here and note to self to bring a knee brace for these downhills next time I hike here in CDMX. The loose volcanic soil and incessant pebbles make for dicey path downhill. We finish the hike at around 1400 and relish some hot cakes at one of the shacks at the base.

                                                                                                                                                                            More than anything, this hike was a major morale booster after last weeks Izta attempt.

                                                                                                                                                                            2024-04-14 09:43:52 - Pico de Águila et Cerro La Cruz del Marquez 🥾 Hiked 4.69 miles in 04:50:29 Pace : 61.94 min/mile. Elevation Gain : 2405 ft. Elevation Loss : 2384 ft. Calories : 1810 Location : La Magdalena Contreras 💓 : 152

It’s how it’s been for thousands of years.

                                                                                                                                                                                        Until 2006. That’s when a Zoroastrian woman living in Mumbai snuck up into the tower and found bloated, rotting bodies everywhere. The vultures were gone. And not just at the tower — all across the country.

A mystery whose stakes are not just the end of an ancient burial practice, but the health of all the world’s ecosystems.

                                                                                                                                                                                                          06 Mar 2022:

                                                                                                                                                                                                          Of late, the NUC has been getting really hot. Core CPU temperatures were hitting the 80s despite the system being on literally no load. When I first bought it in mid-2020, I was aware that this lineage of tiny monsters were known for their ‘hot’ness and the fan being a bit loud.  Only over the last few months have I really seen this sudden spike in temperatures though.

                                                                                                                                                                                                          The first obvious step was to get rid of the plastic lid and get those aluminum heat-sinks. That helped a bit until yesterday when the temps shot to the 90s for no reason. A quick htop run didn’t seem to show any processes that were hogging resources. Troubleshooting this a bit further, I figured I did run some apt updates a few days back that triggered Kernel updates. I might now have to get into the BIOS and see if any firmware updates are pending. As luck might have it though, the current keyboard that I have functions via Bluetooth only and I can’t quite use it to get into the BIOS. I do have an alternate keyboard, again Bluetooth but this one comes with a USB receiver - which I conveniently left in my tech black-box in MD! 🤦 Really hope M doesn’t forget bringing it!

                                                                                                                                                                                                          For now, I installed the cpupower-gui tool and set the Governor to ‘powersave’ mode. Does seem to have done the trick for now. I might have to open up the unit and see if it needs some deep cleaning with some compressed air. Sometime soon I guess!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                              15 Feb 2022:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                #TIL When infected with measles, the immune system takes a reboot and abruptly erases every memory of pathogen it’s had before, essentially making your body vulnerable to infections. Rebuilding immunity takes years…

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                in 2002, a group of Japanese scientists discovered that the receptor the measles virus binds to – a kind of molecular lock that allows it to enter the body – isn’t in the lungs, as you would expect for a respiratory virus. Instead, it’s on cells from the immune system.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                “Measles suppresses the immune system, and activates it at the same time,” says Swart. Though measles deletes immune memories, there is one exception to these losses. Oddly, the only virus you’ll definitely be able to recognise after falling sick with measles is measles itself. The measles paradox

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                This was a fascinating read!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            02 Feb 2022:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              @Morganhousel wrote a fantastic post yesterday outlining how each person’s trajectory is riddled with ‘flukes’. Humanity constantly evolves from a quagmire of possibilities and there’s very little merit in looking in retrospect. I think the likelihood of a successful forecast can only be enhanced if we work with the factors in the present - not the past, not the future. The past is barely helpful and you’d rather not rely on those from the future. (Odd I say that after all those years I spent churning numbers as an actuarial analyst.) Ultimately what trumps is that humans find it really hard to delineate emotions from decision making. As much as you’d like to disagree, you see it in every realm - Medicine, Finance, Sports, Academics, Health just to name a few.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              In 2016, we had a fascinating close call on I-15 S while heading towards New Haven. (Fascinating because, I learnt it the hard way and everyone who drives a car and has a floor-mat should be aware of this.) Accidents tend to give you that moment for retrospect and back then I jotted something similar to the thoughts I have today:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The proverbial – ‘Everything happens for a reason’ is just not true. I believe the human brain does a wonderful job in assigning a reason to the cause and quite conveniently this is always subtly and retrospectively done. In its quest to find reason, it ends up triggering neural connections that emotionally and logically seem reasonable. So when and how do we draw the line while making choices and how do you substantiate the choices you’ve made? Or is the whole premise that as a logical and emotional machine you’re feeding good and bad data (choices) as a stimulus to train the body to better react to unforeseeable situations in the future?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I’ve taken quite some risky shifts in my career over the last decade. Most driven by what I felt at that very moment - Gut instinct. Absolutely none that I regret. And most have been very rewarding. So when it comes to making a choice at that critical moment, I try and keep retrospectives at bay. Every once in a while, I do catch myself careening from this golden rule. That’s when I take a good pause, stop connecting the dots and look at just that isolated dot at that moment. It’s worked wonders before and I trust that streak to continue. Irony being, my previous statement moots everything I said before! What can I say, we’re a good bunch of optimistic morons.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              31 Jan 2022:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                The more that I read and the more that I build, with every additional service that I self-host, I realize there are so many points of failure – each becoming more evident as time passes and experience grows. The blaring one’s get attended to sooner or … https://t.co/UnVzcaZXzy

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Link to Tweet

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                31 Jan 2022:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  The more that I read and the more that I build, with every additional service that I self-host, I realize there are so many points of failure - each becoming more evident as time passes and experience grows. The blaring one’s get attended to sooner or later, and the not-so-urgent one’s remain there - slowly tended to on the whims and fancies of time and interest. Until, from a different perspective, what you judged to be urgent or frivolous flips and then you are just not sure what you are dealing with.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  This must be why it’s so addictive. There are more questions than straightforward solutions. There’s so much uncertainty veiled with the promise of freedom, curiosity and learning. There’s the thrill in making things work despite it being a non-standard approach. And ultimately it’s all yours - the wins and the losses. Well, mostly the losses. But hey, even before you stop to assess, there’s something new round the corner that someone’s built - Intricate yet imperfect. Just what you need to spin-off in that direction…

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  This. is. why? What’s your reason?

I’ve had my eyes on Dex and Ubuntu’s convergence for a while too. For now though, I’m happy with my modular workstation setup. Another stream of thought is to port the fam to a Snikket/XMPP/matrix ecosystem so we’re lesser dependent on external networks. That’s going to take a bit of planning and coaxing though untill the matrix bridges are a bit more robust :).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            22 Aug 2021:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The Bluetooth on my NUC stopped working after an apt upgrade last evening. A good chunk of troubleshooting did no help. My initial hunch was that this was caused by the kernel upgrade. Reverting didn’t help though. I finally caved in and ordered a USB<>Audio adapter. This morning, It struck me that this could be due to the BIOS which I haven’t updated in a while. And I was spot on! Now I have a pretty functional Bluetooth system, an up-to-date machine and yet another adapter which goes into my mystery black-box.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Partner workout day! Let’s call this a loop within loop workout!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Warmup,

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          For ($x = 1,  $x<=7, $x++) {

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • $x Burpee(s) + Within each Burpee [For ($y = 1,  $y<=$x,  $y++) { $y Knee-to-elbow(s) }]
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • $x lying-down-standing-up(s) + Right after lying down [For ($z = 1,  $z<=$x,  $z++) { $z Ab-cycle(s) }]
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Wait for partner to finish similar workout

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          } x As quickly as possible

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cool-down

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              28 May 2021:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                It just struck me today how much I love writing crude, rewarding code. The type that is just sufficient to get the job done and that which ‘scratches your itch’ and might probably be useful for someone else too.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                I am not a software developer. Never been one. My day job is far, far from it. It’s been more than a decade that I’ve worked in a software firm. And even when I did, a good bunch of my time then was spent of mainframe code [Rexx / JCL] and Change Management.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                All code that I write today is self-taught. Which is probably why it’s crude? But beautiful it is, because it challenges me to think of logic first and semantics next. It pushes me to find the quickest way possible because I know exactly what I want it to do. And most importantly it keeps my mind fired and active!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      08 May 2021:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Earlier this week, I came across this nifty python tool that lets you backup all your garmin data from the Garmin-Connect platform. I wrote a crude WordPress plugin to parse the json files over and display the data on my website here. The tool is kind of unstable because it essentially ‘mimics’ a regular Garmin-connect login and download. Also probably the reason why there aren’t many functional plugins for Garmin on wordpress.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Should be reasonably straightforward to automate this with a cron job once I sort out the connection issues with Garmin. Also for now, I’m just posting all the activities to a single page. Might be interesting to create short posts for new activities and obviously filter them out from the RSS Feeds. Love these teeny tiny coding projects!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              30 Apr 2021:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Switched over to consuming Twitter via RSS feeds. For now I am using Yarns on WP to collect the feeds and the Indigenous app / Monocle-web social reader to read/interact with tweets. With this setup, I get to stay clear of the tracking and ads [Last time I checked uBlock Origin blocked 90 trackers/ads in 3 minutes!] and more importantly use my website as the primary place where I post. While I am not quite active on twitter, this should be a great go-between to reconnect with folks who use it for their primary digital presence.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              19 Apr 2021:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                I continue to be amazed at how hassle-free my Nextcloud setup on the RPi3 is! With automated upgrades on the NextxloudPi, I’ve barely had to login to the backend for maintenance. This has been my only file server since 2017 and the best ’tech’ investment so far! There’s absolutely no reason why anyone should be saving their photos/data on someone else’s machine these days!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                18 Apr 2021:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Miss V and I headed over to the Thiruvanmayur coast early this morning. This was her first longish bike ride (~10 mi) and she thoroughly enjoyed it. Riding on the roads here in India calls for a totally different skill-set. If living in a city, you need to ride through traffic to get to the trail/viewpoint and more often than not other vehicles drive totally oblivious of your existence. Miss V weaved in and out while navigating the traffic signals and it was a pleasure seeing her learn the ropes from the corner of my eye. We’re also using bikes that are 20+ years old! So she had to deal with skipping crank-sets and loose chains! I got them to a ride-able condition a few weeks back. However, bike maintenance is overdue and now’s probably the best time to get her into that too.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    24 Mar 2018:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Drove about 3 hours to visit the source of the #Nile. Decided to head to the 'Source of the Nile' restaurant on the west banks of the river instead of the more touristy 'Jinja' side. I think it was a pretty good decision! Beautiful views from the hill and refreshingly windy.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      70% of water apparently originates from Lake Victoria - Which in turn is fed by several streams from various regions nearby and 30% from springs or elsewhere…Pretty surreal being there by the waters!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Drive after Lugazi was pretty straight forward and actually more enjoyable than the section between #Kampala and Lugazi. Most of it was through the Mabira Forest which we went to a few days back.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Tomorrow early AM, we head back to Boston. So glad we decided to 'close-out' this #Uganda trip with the Nile visit!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        22 Mar 2018:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Visited the Wildlife Education center in Entebbe. Incredible experience!#Firsts - Petted a Cheetah on her terms in a controlled wild environment. Followed the guide into the enclosure (the size of a football field) locking the door behind us. He alerted the two cheetahs, calling their names and slowly moved towards them. The two hid amidst the bushes. We approached them cautiously from one end to another. Probably the size of a football field. One continued playing while the other stretched out and lounged on the grass. The guide first approached and petted her and we followed suit. A few minutes later the guide asked us to walk out slowly - us first and he right behind us. Still inside the enclosure for about five to ten minutes, the guide continued answering our questions. The cats were minding their own business least worried about our presence. Eventually got out of the enclosure.Never fathomed I'd be this close to wild animals…Insane experience. Subconsciously I did regulate my breathing with some deep breaths now and then…Looking back, there was no plan B!#TIL Lions are the only cats that hunt in groups. The females hunt mostly for food. Males pitch in only when required and take care of the cubs when the females are out. Males get first dibs, followed by the cubs and only then the females get to eat. Alpha males become the leader of the pack. On some occasions, outcast lions tend to form a pack making them the strongest force in the forest. Quite similar to 'gangs' on the street. While hunting the alpha picks one particular prey and the rest in the pack get the cue and help corner it down. Rest of the non-chosen one's are NOT attacked even if they're an easy target. #Firsts - Fed a Giraffe and learnt they're mostly silent! Their hearts are pretty big and weight about 10Kilos#Firsts - Met the insanely wise looking Shoebill! This one socializes by nodding its head downwards and 'clapping' with its beak!#Firsts - Met about 20 chimps and realised how insanely similar they were to Humans. One little one was using a long twig to fetch bananas from the stream. Could easily pass off for a human kid. No kidding!#TIL about the Keystone Species! Reminded me about the Alabama Sturgeon and the introduction of wolves to save an ecosystem.

Idi Amin's torture chambers… A 93 year old temple that Idi Amin surprisingly didn't flatten…Unlike portrayed in most history books, Gaddafi is not considered a tyrant here by the Bugandese people!…The first son of the Bugandan King apparently would be the chief advisor and never gets to take the throne…

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            20 Mar 2018:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              On the drive back to #Kampala we were stuck in a traffic jam. A tempo wanting to cross over to the other side, decided to cut in from one of the feeder roads, essentially blocking the traffic on the opposite direction. Noticing this, the mini-van on the opposite side veered off the road and on to the sidewalk behind the tempo circumventing it and casually got back on the road. Other vehicles followed suite. I backed out a bit to let the tempo cross and he gleefully went his way.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Absolutely no horns or visual stress on any of the drivers! Can't imagine this happening in India. Absolutely love driving here!
